H0.text: Fish → Plants → Birds is the best representation of the energy transfer between animals in a shoreline ecosystem, illustrating that all organisms depend on energy transfer to survive.

H1.text: Plants -> Birds -> Fish is the best representation of the energy transfer among animals in a shoreline ecosystem, illustrating how all organisms depend on energy transfer to survive.

H2.text: Plants → Fish → Birds is the best way to show the energy transfer between animals in a shoreline ecosystem, given that all organisms depend on the transfer of energy to survive.

H3.text: Fish → Birds → Plants best illustrates the energy transfer between animals in a shoreline ecosystem, showing how energy moves from fish to birds to plants as all organisms depend on energy transfer to survive.

A4.text: Plants and algae do not usually eat other organisms, but pull nutrients from the soil or the ocean and manufacture their own food using photosynthesis. For this reason, they are called primary producers.

A5.text: Virtually all plants and phytoplankton are purely phototrophic and are at exactly level 1.0. Many worms are at around 2.1; insects 2.2; jellyfish 3.0; birds 3.6.
